explanation:
Correct calculation: \( 30 \, \text{g} \times 1000 \, \frac{\text{mg}}{\text{g}} = 30000 \, \text{mg} \).  
Student's incorrect step: \( 30 \, \text{g} \times 10 = 300 \, \text{mg} \).  

The student incorrectly used a factor of 10 instead of 1000 for the gram-to-milligram conversion. This indicates they conflated the metric prefix "milli-" (which denotes \( \times 10^{-3} \)) with "deci-" (which denotes \( \times 10^{-1} \)), leading them to multiply by 10 rather than 1000.  

This error aligns with misunderstanding the relationship between metric prefixes: the student failed to recognize that "milli-" requires scaling by \( 1000 \times \). Unlike the related misconception of confusing "milli-" with "centi-" (which would produce \( 30 \times 100 = 3000 \)), the student's answer directly reflects a 10× scaling, showing confusion with a smaller decimal prefix.
